questions.question_text: A technician logs onto a system using Telnet because SSH is unavailable. SSH is enabled on the target device, and access is allowed from all subnets. The technician discovers a critical step was missed. Which of the following would allow SSH to function properly?

discussion.content:
Generating new keys is the most correct answer. SSH uses RSA public key infrastructure for both signature and encryption. With new keys the technician's device should have no issue using SSH to access the remote system.
File hashing is incorrect. This has no impact on connectivity.
Updating firmware is incorrect. This is too broad a measure and may require a change document.
Changing default credentials is incorrect. Since the remote system is already up it is implied that its default credentials are already changed.

I am confused. If he is able to authenticate to the database successfully but lose connection afterward, how is this an ACL issue? If it's an ACL issue, then it would deny access, all the time, every time.
ACL configuration IS correct here. It makes the most sense, after doing a lot of research of how ACLs and NTP work in the networks.
ntp synch

comments.content: I was also thinking this but now that I think a little more I believe if the NTP wasnâ€™t synced these you would probably not even be able to authenticate to the database

discussion.content: in another way, by the way of elimination, it's the only option D that is reasonable.
Can someone please explain this, thanks

comments.content:
I believe 
Correct is Access Control Lists (ACLs) since it Deny or permit traffic

questions.question_text: A server rack was moved from one floor to another. The network engineer needs to determine what physical changes to make on the network to ensure the server rack has connectivity. Which of the following should the network engineer consult?

discussion.content:
PaaS = Platform as a service. 
This answer is wrong and hurts the integrity and authenticity of this website. If the datacenter is running it's own private cloud and needs assistance from a seperate third-party cloud to enable bursting the capacity at peak hours, this is called hybrid cloud. Platform as a Service in no way shape-or-form helps at all with this unless you wan't to offload the ENTIRE workload onto the hosting partie's platform and use none of your datacenter. The answer is bogus and should be changed ASAP

comments.content: The datacenter isn't specified to be on the cloud, so it's likely an on-site datacenter

discussion.content: Hybrid, a combination of on-site and in cloud solution.
I think it is Paas because it would offer the fastest resolution and cheapest. Imagine having the vm and os ready you just load up the apps.

Selected Answer: D
This looks like a Hybrid cloud because they want to not pay for extra hardware so they go somewhere else to pick up the load. BaaS could be one as well but that is not an option so BEST answer is D.

Selected Answer: D
Answer is D

Selected Answer: C
Answer is C

on premise hardware = infrastructure
They need to purchase IAAS which would put them in a hybrid situation

Selected Answer: D
Wrong answer, hybrid is both on-premise and on cloud
The question is not what would the data center become, but what would aid it. Therefore, PaaS is correct. If it were the former question the answer would be hybrid.

Selected Answer: D
Hybrid. Admins do your job and "expertly verify" the answers.

Selected Answer: D
Cloud bursting is a deployment model that runs applications in a data center or private cloud, and then bursts into public clouds, as needed, when computing demands spike. This type of hybrid cloud deployment enables organizations to pay for extra computing resources on-demand. Answer =D.

So I originally also thought Hybrid Cloud because that is what it is, but that's not what the question is asking. The question is asking which of these would aid in this scenario and PaaS is what would aid in creating the Hybrid Cloud.

Selected Answer: D
Hybrid, a combination of on-site and in cloud solution.
It's wearying to have to second- and third-guess so many of these answers.

" but does not want to pay for on-premises hardware that is not used during off-peak times"
in order words cost-efficient
Cloud bursting is in Mike Meyer's book - application can grow into a public cloud - in the HYBRID Cloud section. So I am selecting D.
I honestly can't wrap my head around this question and set of answers. On to the next....

PaaS advantages 
Other advantages include the following:

Cost Effective: No need to purchase hardware or pay expenses during downtime
Time Savings: No need to spend time setting up/maintaining the core stack
Speed to Market: Speed up the creation of apps
Future-Proof: Access to state-of-the-art data center, hardware and operating systems
Increase Security: PaaS providers invest heavily in security technology and expertise
Dynamically Scale: Rapidly add capacity in peak times and scale down as needed
Custom Solutions: Operational tools in place so developers can create custom software
Flexibility: Allows employees to log in and work on applications from anywhere.
Thought it was Hybrid at first, but had to read through again.
PaaS is what the company would purchase to run extra capacity remotely. Once they purchase this capability, they are running a hybrid cloud but that is not what they had to buy.
This a cloud+ question not a network+ question. Plus hybrid cloud is the correct answer
If the network admin is considering to pay the third party so it is called hybrid yet he did not consider it and stick to his own rule so the answer is PaaS.
Hybrid

Cloud bursting is an application deployment model in which an application runs in a private cloud or data center and bursts into a public cloud when the demand for computing capacity spikes. The advantage of such a hybrid cloud deployment is that an organization only pays for extra compute resources when they are needed. Therefore, answer should be "Hybrid Cloud"
This question is tricky. If the enterprise do not want pay for hardware, It would use the Platform .
The question didn't say the company used their own private cloud to create the database...
nepa is Correct. PaaS is mainly used for Developers who need to create applications with an infrastructure in place

questions.question_text: A network administrator needs to be able to burst datacenter capacity during peak times, but does not want to pay for on-premises hardware that is not used during off-peak times. Which of the following would aid in this scenario?

A user wants to secure a network closet and be able to tell if anyone makes changes in the closet. Which of the following would be the BEST detective physical security devices in this situation? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Tamper and Video seem the best answers to me based mostly on the wording of the question: "to tell if anyone makes changes in the closet". Tamper tells you if changes were made and video tells you who/how/when.

Under CompTIA's physical security "detection" they review motion, video, asset tracking and tamper detection. From reading their book it seems to push you to choosing tampering and video. Motion is listed but is it the "best"? I am going with A and F

comments.content: After thinking about it more, a would be the best fit.

discussion.content: Its states the BEST detective physical devices. Video surveillance and motion detection seems to fit to me.

Hello, why answer A nad F? Answer A is mean (Cryptography is an effective way to prevent the loss of information in the form of data. Anti-tamper technology, on the other hand, protects software that cannot be secured by cryptography by making reverse engineering more difficult. Using these two technologies together prevents leaks of both data and software.)
My suggestens is B and F?
Thanks.
